Award.AwardTitle: RUI - Preparation, Characterization, and Theoretical Modeling of Organometallic Porphyrins and Tetraazaporphyrins
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Nemykin of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at University of Minnesota Duluth (UMD) will explore synthetic pathways for the preparation of organometallic porphyrins and their aromatic macrocyclic analogues. While chemistry of simple organometallic compounds (i.e. ferrocenes) is well-explored, little progress has been made in the development of organometallic aromatic macrocycles. Dr. Nemykin and others have recently shown that introduction of organometallic substituents into the porphyrin core results in rare long-range metal-metal coupling properties, which are essential for the application of such compounds in molecular electronics, random access memory devices and components for near infra-red optical limiters. Electrochemical, spectroelectrochemical, and chemical oxidation methods will be used to identify the properties of the target compounds.

This work could result in the preparation of efficient modules for molecular electronics and redox-driven sensors. Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on any area in which the synthesis of molecules is needed, such as microelectronics, environmental engineering, as well as biological and chemical research activities. In addition, this project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate (M.S.) students, as well as for a post-doctoral researcher who will be both teaching and conducting research in preparation for a career at a predominantly undergraduate institution.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota Duluth
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research was to continue combined experimental and theoretical work on the synthesis and characterization of metallocenyl-containing porphyrins and their analogues. In particular, we were interested in three research directions:

  1. Preparation of the specially designed molecules useful for molecular electronics and specifically molecules-based random access memory (RAM) modules. Current RAM modules in computers, phones, and the other devices use silicon technology, which is already pushed to the limits. Usage of specifically designed molecules in RAM would allow increasing an information density and decreasing power consumption in regular electronics devices. NSF support allowed us to investigate a degree of electronic communications between several substituents in the same molecule, which can be used in two- and four-bit RAM.  
  2. Design of organometallic compounds with redox-switchable fluorescence properties. We are interested in creation of the molecules in which initial fluorescence would be suppressed by organometallic substituents. Upon oxidation with environmentally hazardous oxidants or by natural oxidants in the living cells, these compounds with restore fluorescence, which would allow to monitor the concentrations of environmental or natural oxidants in the environment. NSF support allowed us to create variety of new compounds, which would restore fluorescence upon exposure to hazardous oxidants.
  3. Synthesis of organometallic molecules useful for light-harvesting applications. Solar energy-to-electricity conversion is of the largest challenges for mankind. During NSF supported research, we were able to create a set of organometallic donor-acceptor assemblies, which have potential in light-harvesting. These systems are currently being studied as prospective modules for organic photovoltaics.

 

    UMD is a predominantly undergraduate school and thus our educational goals were to provide excellent training in synthesis, spectroscopy and electronic structure calculations to B.S. and M.S. students and to further strengthen undergraduate research programs at the University of Minnesota Duluth. The specifically designed modular character of the proposed project is especially suitable for undergraduate research and for training a new generation of chemists in the fields of inorganic and organometallic chemistry. Conducted research stimulates non-traditional thinking and advance undergraduate students to the frontier of modern, fundamental chemistry. It also strengthens the M.S. graduate program at the University of Minnesota Duluth, which has proven to be beneficial to our predominantly undergraduate research program.


Last Modified: 09/07/2015
Modified by: Viktor N Nemykin

Design of organometallic compounds with redox-switchable fluorescence properties. We are interested in creation of the molecules in which initial fluorescence would be suppressed by organometallic substituents. Upon oxidation with environmentally hazardous oxidants or by natural oxidants in the living cells, these compounds with restore fluorescence, which would allow to monitor the concentrations of environmental or natural oxidants in the environment. NSF support allowed us to create variety of new compounds, which would restore fluorescence upon exposure to hazardous oxidants. Synthesis of organometallic molecules useful for light-harvesting applications. Solar energy-to-electricity conversion is of the largest challenges for mankind. During NSF supported research, we were able to create a set of organometallic donor-acceptor assemblies, which have potential in light-harvesting. The specifically designed modular character of the proposed project is especially suitable for undergraduate research and for training a new generation of chemists in the fields of inorganic and organometallic chemistry. Conducted research stimulates non-traditional thinking and advance undergraduate students to the frontier of modern, fundamental chemistry. It also strengthens the M.S. graduate program at the University of Minnesota Duluth, which has proven to be beneficial to our predominantly undergraduate research program.
